title: 112_hr6530
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products across borders. Policies should encourage the use of international technology standards and prioritize the security and privacy of Internet users. The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 aims to uphold a free, open Internet by promoting investment in innovation, respecting user privacy, and allowing trade in Internet-related goods and services. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that go against this goal. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies contrary to a free, open Internet, including mandating unique technology standards favoring domestic producers and sponsoring unauthorized access to networks in the United States. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies to gain unauthorized access to networks in the United States, disrupt operations, discriminate against Internet-based services from other countries, restrict privacy and freedom, and impose discriminatory market access requirements. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that threaten the interests of the United States by facilitating attempts to restrict the free flow of information on the Internet and promoting "national Internets" in conflict with the original architecture of the Internet. The Internet's functionality and promise are compromised by certain governments and international bodies adopting policies that harm US workers and businesses, undermine the strong US industrial base, and put foreign competitors at an advantage. This also risks the utility of the Internet as a tool for open communication, assembly, and commerce. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established to address policies that harm US workers and businesses, undermine the industrial base, and put foreign competitors at an advantage. The Task Force on the Global Internet, hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of four US persons with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, selected by the President to serve as Chairperson. The Task Force on the Global Internet, under the Department of Commerce, comprises four US individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties. They are nominated by the public and appointed by the President through the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology. The appointed members serve renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. Additionally, the majority and minority party leaders in the Senate each appoint members. The Task Force for the Global Internet, under the Department of Commerce, is responsible for developing and implementing strategies to address government policies that impede the free flow of information on the Internet, threaten the open nature of the Internet, and impact Internet-related international trade and discourse. The Task Force consults with civil society groups, coordinates Federal departments and agencies, and prepares reports and action plans. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN TO THE PRESIDENT AND CONGRESS. The Task Force will annually report to the President and Congress on acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access or burden trade. The Task Force will report annually to the President and Congress on measures that deny fair market access, burden trade, or threaten US interests in Internet-related goods and services. The Task Force will annually report to the President and Congress on measures that impact US interests in Internet-related goods and services, including trade-distorting impacts, suppression of free expression, and priority concerns, with a strategy for action. The Task Force will report annually to the President and Congress on priority concerns, setting forth a strategy and actions to be taken by Federal departments and agencies in response to identified measures. Reports may include a classified annex if deemed appropriate. The Task Force may include a classified annex in its reports and action plans if deemed necessary. Public participation is encouraged through notices in the Federal Register, public hearings, and a dedicated website for the Task Force. The Task Force is required to consult with relevant departments, engage with civil society groups, and consider information from various sources. The Task Force, consisting of groups knowledgeable in Internet policy and civil liberties, must consider information from various sources, including reports and petitions submitted to the Trade Representative. The report and action plan will be published in the Federal Register, excluding information sent to Congress. The Task Force, comprised of experts in Internet policy and civil liberties, will publish the report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding details sent to Congress. SEC. 5. SECTION 301 INVESTIGATION AND POTENTIAL SANCTIONS. The United States Trade Representative must initiate an investigation within 30 days of each annual report and action plan submission. This investigation will address priority concerns regarding foreign government or international body acts, policies, or practices that restrict the sale of products in the United States. SEC. 6. REVIEW AND INVESTIGATION BY FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION AND DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General review and investigate acts, policies, or practices to determine if they violate antitrust laws. The term "antitrust laws" is defined in the Clayton Act. The term "antitrust laws" is defined in the Clayton Act, including section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act for unfair competition. SEC. 7. REPORT TO CONGRESS ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE AGREEMENTS. The Task Force must submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The report will assess existing trade agreements' effectiveness in promoting international trade in Internet-related goods, services, and content, encouraging global technology standards, protecting Internet security, and facilitating the free flow of information. The Task Force report will assess existing trade agreements' effectiveness in promoting international trade in Internet-related goods, services, and content, encouraging global technology standards, protecting Internet security, facilitating the free flow of information, and protecting the interests of Internet users. Congress recommends including these goals in future trade agreements. The United States' negotiating objectives for trade agreements should align with specified goals. Reports may include a classified annex if deemed necessary. Public participation is encouraged through notices, comments submission, and public hearings. The Task Force must consult with relevant departments, hold public hearings, and establish a website for public comments. They should also coordinate with civil society groups with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties. The Task Force must consult with relevant departments, hold public hearings, establish a website for public comments, and coordinate with civil society groups with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties. They should also share timely information with civil society groups and consider information from sources available to the United States Trade Representative. The Task Force will publish the report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding information sent to Congress under subsection (b). SEC. 8. STANDARDS-RELATED TRAINING. The Task Force will coordinate with various entities for training foreign and domestic officials on best practices in standards-setting, including collaboration with international bodies. The Task Force will establish a process for receiving input from businesses, organizations, experts, and other parties regarding its functions.
